Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MRJ My uro wrote a prescription to a compounding pharmacy for generic cialis. $150 for 30 5MG troches. If you are in the US, Cialis is still on-patent. No physician should be writing you a prescription for a generic, which is why you should question this claim. Viagra is off-patent in the US, and generic options may be available.

Posts.Title: This Crazy Disease

Posts.Content: ISZ- I can't say that I'm completely familiar with your situation, and you seem like you're in a damned if you do, damned if you don't kind of situation. I would work with my doctor to get your testosterone levels back where they're comfortable and decreasing all of these other nasty side effects. But, I would also discuss active surveillance of your prostate so that if you do come down with PC, you catch it early and can act on it quickly. Sometimes with medicine and disease, you have to weigh side effects and your best quality of life. I wish you well.

Posts.Title: Well it appears I am not immortal....testosterone related

Posts.Content: I think your friend is highly misinformed. First of all, there are hundreds of different types of cancers--they are not all contained in "balloon" packages that rupture when you poke them. Cancer by itself is not "poisonous" but rather the result of the body's own inability to control cellular growth. There may be many ways, including thermography, of detecting things in the body that look like cancer. But you'll never know the difference, nor will you know the makeup of the cancer without a pathologist sampling it. Knowing exactly the type of cancer and the cause is crucial sometimes, in selecting the proper treatment. I am very much insulted with the statement that people with cancer have not been cured. My cancer was treated for a curative result. It has been three years for me, and I'm cancer-free, thank God. I have others around me that are also living proof that cancer can be cured--my mother had lung cancer, and my mother in-law had breast cancer. People do know what "remission" means, and two months is not the standard metric. A durable remission can, and does last for many years. Does it happen for all cancer patients? no, it does not, because cancer is a complex disease. There is no single therapy that works for everyone. And yet, modern medicine--the kind that undergoes clinical trials is proven with statistical methods--has come so far from traditional, cytotoxic chemotherapy. We have targeted medicines that single out pathways for cancer growth; we have immuno-therapies that trigger or help the body's own immune system to fight off cancer. There are breakthroughs in these approaches every year. In a decade, we may wonder why we ever used chemotherapy for some cancers. I'm sorry for your diagnosis, and wish you all the best as far as your treatments and recovery go. But your friend is more guilty of scare tactics than any oncologist I've encountered. If you take advice from your father's friend, rather than a trained medical doctor, you may end up with vastly different results.

Posts.Title: Alternative Medicine Claims

Posts.Content: I am a head & neck cancer survivor, so I cannot speak specifically to prostate cancer, but I'd like to share my thoughts. First, I think it's wise that you're considering the "big picture." I think all cancer patients have to deal with two basic options: 1) don't treat; 2) treat and deal with the side-effects. Sometimes, the side effects are so severe and the subsequent quality of life so degraded that the patients elect not to treat. If no treatment is taken, that patient may succumb relatively quick to the growing cancer inside their body. That is choice to weigh. If a treatment is taken, the patient must deal with any side effects which could remain to some degree, for their remainder of their lives. That said, if the treatment allows the patient to live a relatively long and mostly-normal life, is dealing with the side-effects a good trade-off? When it came to "signing off" on my treatment (one that included RT, targeted monoclonal antibodies and subsequent surgery), I had complete faith in my medical team, including my oncologist. They presented me with the potential outcomes and side-effects, though to be honest, I could not have anticipated the degree at which some of the effects were felt. Some things, like my swallowing, are still a slight issue three years out. But I'm cancer-free, and I'm enjoying my family and friends and life, nearly as before. If your father's health is in good shape and he would otherwise have many good years in front of him, I'd advise him to talk with his doctors, ensuring he understands all the options and their outcomes. If he elects for the HT and there are side effects, can they be managed? Cancer changes everyone to some degree; you (or your father) must ask whether or not the "juice is worth the squeeze," so to speak.

Posts.Content: Those are all great points, Djin. Honestly, books could be written about all the specifics that go into clinical trials (and they have!) I tried to emphasize some points that I thought visitors to this forum would find interesting. I am involved with a lot of early-phase clinical trials in my line of work, dealing specifically with the study drug. In many of the Phase 1 trials, I see a lot of blinding performed by the site pharmacist. Typically, they prepare a dose of either study drug or placebo, then give it to the clinician for administering to the patient. Again, great job with the initial content!

Posts.Title: How Many Angels Can Dance on the Edge of a Pin

Posts.Content: Hello, Djin--very good information you shared. I would like to add a couple comments about "blinded" trials. To prevent bias from creeping into some trials, sometimes, the study design will incorporate blinding. Blinding can be done in several ways, but the two main types are: - Single-Blind: this means the patient alone is not aware of the treatment they're receiving. - Double-Blind: this means that both the patient AND the doctor or clinician administering the medicine is not aware of the treatment they're administering or receiving. The treatment--the medicine used in a clinical trial--can be blinded in a number of different ways. It can be blinded by manufacturing the control medicine and the study drug to look the same way; i.e., same color, shape, size, package or label. In some cases, it's not possible to alter the medicine's appearance, so the packaging may include some kind of barrier to prevent patients or clinicians from seeing the material. Sometimes, the study drug is blinded to see how it performs against a comparative drug, and sometimes a study drug is used against a placebo, to see the difference in results. A placebo is a non-medicinal product that looks like the study drug, but contains no active ingredients. (Typically, these are made of starch-like materials.) It should also be known that for serious, life-threatening diseases (including cancers), it is considered unethical to administer only placebo to a patient. For cancer patients, it's typical to choose a treatment that's considered a standard of care (SOC) for a particular disease. For example, enzalutamide is often given to prostate cancer patients, and would be considered a SOC for that disease. A study design could include that SOC + placebo as a control group in one arm, and the SOC + a different study drug in the test arm. In both arms, the SOC is given, but never placebo alone. I hope others find this helpful.

Posts.Title: Anatomy of a Clinical Trial

Posts.Content: Personally, I would not get too caught up in the "x" value, favoring one doctor over another. You can quickly get to a point of diminishing returns, when all you really might need is a surgeon with a reasonable amount of experience. Before any surgery, discuss the procedure with your doctor or surgeon. Ask them questions such as, - How many of these types of surgeries have you performed? - What is the typical outcome? - Is there anything about MY situation that concerns you, anything that might present a problem that could affect the outcome? - What risks, if any, come with this surgery? (They should spell all of these out in the consent form--if you see anything that alarms you, you should definitely ask about it.) - Should I expect any side effects from the surgery? Will it be permanent or if not, how long should my recovery be until I return to normal? I'm sure there are many other questions you could ask, but have a discussion. When you do, gauge the comfort level of your doctor--are they completely comfortable with the procedure? Do they sound confident, or do they have concerns? If you feel at all like they may not be the best for you, ask them if you should seek another surgeon.

No other "classic" cancer symptoms late Feb, 2013 - Visited PCP for check-up, PCP advised as lymphoma. Did blood work, orders for CT-scan, referred to ENT 3/7/13 - CT-scan inconclusive, endoscopy negative 3/9/13 - FNA of neck mass 3/14/13 - Received dx of squamous-cell carcinoma, unknown primary 3/25/13 - CT-PET scan reveals no other active tumors 3/26/13 - work/up for IMRT 4/1/13 - W1, D1 of weekly cetuximab 4/8/13 - W1, D1 of IMRT 5/20/13 - complete 8 week regimen of weekly cetuximab 5/24/13 - Complete 35-day regimen of daily IMRT mid-July 2013 - CT-PET scan reveals no active tumors, but shows necrotic tissue at site of original tumor early Sept 2013 - partial neck dissection to remove necrotic tissue. Assay shows no cancer present. Spring 2014 - No signs of cancer Spring 2015 - NED Spring 2016 - NED Spring 2017 - NED Spring 2018 - NED

Posts.Title: 24 hour countdown

Posts.Content: Good story, and I'm sure your fellow traveler is appreciative of the experience. There are a little over 30 million people in Uzbekistan, which is about one-tenth the size of the United States. While there may have been no cost to this woman, someone paid for the medical care. Someone paid for the x-ray machine; someone paid for the surgeon, assisting nurses, anesthesia, and any other tools used during the surgery. Someone will have to pay the janitors to clean up after all that work. Who pays? What if that same person showed up complaining of abdominal pain, and that pain turned out to be related to pancreatic cancer? How would they have treated that? There's no such thing as a "free lunch," there's always a cost. The treatment this woman received was pretty straightforward and basic; I'm not denying that it sounds like a really good experience, but there are limitations to what the model you described can do.

Posts.Title: OT - Communist health care - they have that right

Posts.Content: Duragesic is a narcotic for moderate to severe and chronic pain; i.e., not occasional aches and pains. The literature does mention hallucinations, but I would imagine those are present regardless of which opioid medicine is prescribed. http://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsa...813s039lbl.pdf I myself, used oxycodone for pain in my mouth and throat associated with radiation. It was effective, and worked for me. You would probably be better off discussing pain management with your doctor, who can tell you the benefits and trade-offs about one painkiller over another. Best wishes.
